questions.text: When pepsin acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: B
options.text: 1 F(ab')₂ and a degraded Fc fragment

questions.correct_answer: B. 1 F(ab')₂ and a degraded Fc fragment
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 F(ab')₂ and a degraded Fc fragment

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • When pepsin acts on an immunoglobulin molecule, it cleaves below the disulfide bonds in the hinge region of the heavy chains. This results in the formation of one F(ab')₂ fragment, which contains both antigen-binding sites connected by disulfide bonds, and a degraded Fc fragment composed of smaller peptides.
  • • Pepsin digestion differs from papain digestion, which cleaves above the disulfide bonds and produces two Fab fragments and one Fc fragment.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments : Incorrect. This is the result of digestion with papain, not pepsin.
  • • Option A. 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments
  • • Option C. 1 Variable chain and 1 constant chain : Incorrect. This is not the result of enzymatic cleavage by either papain or pepsin.
  • • Option C. 1 Variable chain and 1 constant chain
  • • Option D. 2 Fc and 2 Fab fragments : Incorrect. Such fragmentation is not observed with enzymatic digestion of immunoglobulins.
  • • Option D. 2 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the genetics of G6PD Deficiency is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • G6PD deficiency follows an X-linked inheritance pattern, with the gene located on the X chromosome. The Lyon hypothesis (X-chromosome inactivation) actually explains why some heterozygous females can be affected by G6PD deficiency, though typically less severely than males. During early embryonic development, one X chromosome in each female cell is randomly inactivated. If a higher proportion of cells have the normal X chromosome inactivated, these females can express symptoms of G6PD deficiency. This variable inactivation creates a mosaic pattern in heterozygous females rather than contradicting the hypothesis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. X-linked inheritance - This is correct. G6PD deficiency is indeed an X-linked recessive disorder, which places males at much higher risk for symptomatic disease.
  • • Option A. X-linked inheritance
  • • Option B. More severe in males - This is correct. Since males have only one X chromosome, if they inherit the defective G6PD gene, they will express the disorder fully, making the condition typically more severe in males.
  • • Option B. More severe in males
  • • Option D. May affect heterozygous females - This is correct. Heterozygous females can be affected due to random X-inactivation, where some cells express the defective G6PD gene, potentially leading to clinical manifestations.
  • • Option D. May affect heterozygous females

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that follows the principles of the Lyon hypothesis, with males being more severely affected, while heterozygous females may show variable expression depending on X-chromosome inactivation patterns.

questions.text: In which of the following processes does one cell engulf another cell without degrading it? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Emperipolesis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Emperipolesis is the process in which one cell actively enters another cell but remains intact without being degraded. Unlike entosis, in which the engulfed cell is digested by the host cell, emperipolesis allows the engulfed cell to persist and sometimes exit the host cell later. This phenomenon is seen in physiological and pathological processes, such as in immune surveillance or during interactions between cancer and immune cells.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Necrosis : Incorrect. Necrosis is an uncontrolled form of cell death due to injury or damage, leading to cell lysis and inflammation. It does not involve a cell-in-cell appearance.
  • • Option A. Necrosis
  • • Option B. Apoptosis : Incorrect. Apoptosis is a programmed form of cell death characterized by apoptotic bodies and phagocytosis of the remnants, but it does not involve a cell-in-cell structure.
  • • Option B. Apoptosis
  • • Option D. Entosis : Incorrect. Entosis is a process where one cell actively engulfs another cell, leading to its degradation within lysosomes, creating a characteristic "cell-in-cell" appearance.
  • • Option D. Entosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Emperipolesis is distinct from other processes like entosis, as it involves the engulfment of one cell into another without degradation. Understanding this phenomenon is crucial in identifying its roles in immune regulation and pathological conditions like cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is protective against Alzheimer’s disease? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Apo E2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Apolipoprotein E2 (Apo E2) is associated with a decreased risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease. It is believed to have a protective effect due to its role in promoting the efficient clearance of amyloid-beta from the brain, which is a key pathological feature of Alzheimer's disease. Among the ApoE alleles, ApoE2 has the lowest affinity for amyloid-beta and is less likely to contribute to plaque formation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Apo E1 : Incorrect. Apo E1 is not commonly associated with Alzheimer’s disease or its risk profile.
  • • Option A. Apo E1
  • • Option C. Apo E3 : Incorrect. Apo E3 is the most prevalent allele in the population and is considered neutral in terms of Alzheimer’s disease risk.
  • • Option C. Apo E3
  • • Option D. Apo E4 : Incorrect. Apo E4 is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease, increasing both the risk and the severity of the disease.
  • • Option D. Apo E4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While Apo E4 increases the risk of Alzheimer’s disease, Apo E2 is protective due to its role in reducing amyloid-beta accumulation in the brain. Understanding the roles of ApoE alleles in Alzheimer’s disease can inform genetic counseling and research on therapeutic interventions.

She has a history of seasonal allergies and reports exacerbations triggered by pollen exposure. Laboratory tests show elevated serum IgE levels, and she experiences rapid onset of symptoms shortly after exposure to the allergen. Which of the following cells is primarily responsible for the acute symptoms observed in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mast cells

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient’s symptoms are characteristic of seasonal allergic asthma , which is a type I hypersensitivity reaction. The key feature here is the rapid onset of symptoms (wheezing, cough, and shortness of breath) shortly after exposure to an allergen (e.g., pollen), which points to an immediate-type hypersensitivity reaction. In this type of allergic reaction, mast cells play a central role.
  • • seasonal allergic asthma
  • • rapid onset of symptoms
  • • immediate-type hypersensitivity
  • • mast cells
  • • Mast cells (Option A) are the primary effector cells in Type I hypersensitivity reactions. When the patient’s IgE (Option C) binds to mast cells, it sensitizes them. Upon subsequent exposure to the allergen, mast cells degranulate and release histamine and other mediators that cause the acute symptoms (such as bronchoconstriction and mucosal inflammation). Eosinophils (Option B) are involved in the late-phase inflammatory response (the chronic phase ) of asthma and allergies, but they are not responsible for the acute symptoms in this case. IgE (Option C) is critical in sensitizing mast cells but does not directly cause the symptoms itself. It binds to mast cells, and when the allergen interacts with the IgE, it triggers mast cell degranulation. Neutrophils (Option D) are involved in Type III hypersensitivity reactions and infections, but they are not central to the allergic responses seen in asthma.
  • • Mast cells (Option A) are the primary effector cells in Type I hypersensitivity reactions. When the patient’s IgE (Option C) binds to mast cells, it sensitizes them. Upon subsequent exposure to the allergen, mast cells degranulate and release histamine and other mediators that cause the acute symptoms (such as bronchoconstriction and mucosal inflammation).
  • • Mast cells
  • • primary effector cells
  • • Type I hypersensitivity
  • • IgE
  • • Eosinophils (Option B) are involved in the late-phase inflammatory response (the chronic phase ) of asthma and allergies, but they are not responsible for the acute symptoms in this case.
  • • Eosinophils
  • • late-phase
  • • chronic phase
  • • acute symptoms
  • • IgE (Option C) is critical in sensitizing mast cells but does not directly cause the symptoms itself. It binds to mast cells, and when the allergen interacts with the IgE, it triggers mast cell degranulation.
  • • IgE
  • • Neutrophils (Option D) are involved in Type III hypersensitivity reactions and infections, but they are not central to the allergic responses seen in asthma.
  • • Neutrophils
  • • Type III hypersensitivity reactions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Type I hypersensitivity reactions (like allergic asthma), mast cells are the key players responsible for the acute symptoms, with IgE being crucial for mast cell sensitization.
  • ➤ Type I hypersensitivity
  • ➤ mast cells
  • ➤ acute
  • ➤ IgE

questions.text: On a histopathological slide of an atherosclerotic plaque, what does the presence of needle-shaped empty spaces indicate? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In atherosclerotic plaques, the characteristic needle-shaped empty spaces observed on histopathology represent cholesterol clefts. These spaces form when cholesterol crystals are dissolved during routine tissue processing, leaving behind characteristic empty clefts. They are typically found in the necrotic core of the atherosclerotic plaque, alongside foam cells, necrotic debris, fibrin, and other plasma proteins. These crystalline cholesterol deposits contribute to the "grumous" (soft and friable) nature of the lipid core in advanced atheromas.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Foam Cells - These are lipid-laden macrophages and smooth muscle cells found in atherosclerotic plaques, but they appear as cells with foamy cytoplasm due to accumulated lipid droplets, not as empty needle-shaped spaces. Foam cells are a key feature of atherosclerotic lesions, particularly in early fatty streaks.
  • • Option B. Foam Cells
  • • Option C. Smooth Muscle Cells - These cells are present in atherosclerotic plaques, particularly in the fibrous cap, but they appear as spindle-shaped cells with nuclei, not as empty spaces. Smooth muscle cells play an important role in plaque stabilization through ECM production.
  • • Option C. Smooth Muscle Cells
  • • Option D. Glycogen - Glycogen deposits appear as clear spaces within cell cytoplasm but have a different morphology than cholesterol clefts and are not typically a prominent feature of atherosclerotic plaques. Glycogen is more commonly observed in glycogen storage diseases or in certain liver pathologies.
  • • Option D. Glycogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholesterol clefts, appearing as characteristic needle-shaped empty spaces in histopathology, are hallmark features of advanced atherosclerotic plaques, representing crystalline cholesterol deposits that have been dissolved during tissue processing.

questions.text: An affected male does not have affected children, but 50% of the offspring of an affected female are affected, regardless of sex. Type of inheritance? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) X-linked dominant

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • X-linked dominant inheritance is a pattern in which a gene located on the X chromosome causes a condition that can affect both males and females. The distinguishing feature of X-linked dominant inheritance is that affected males cannot pass the trait to their sons (since males pass only the Y chromosome to their sons), but they pass it to all of their daughters. An affected female has a 50% chance of passing the trait to each offspring, regardless of sex.
  • • Key Features of X-Linked Dominant Inheritance:
  • • Both males and females can be affected, but females are often less severely affected due to the presence of a second normal X chromosome.
  • • Affected males pass the condition to all daughters but not to their sons.
  • • Affected females pass the condition to 50% of their offspring (both sons and daughters).
  • • Examples of X-linked dominant conditions:
  • • Rett syndrome Fragile X syndrome (in females) Hypophosphatemic rickets
  • • Rett syndrome
  • • Fragile X syndrome (in females)
  • • Hypophosphatemic rickets
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. X-linked recessive : Incorrect. In X-linked recessive inheritance, males are more frequently affected, and females are typically carriers. Affected males do not pass the condition to their sons, but daughters may become carriers.
  • • Option A. X-linked recessive
  • • Option B. Autosomal recessive : Incorrect. Autosomal recessive conditions require both parents to pass on a copy of the mutated gene, leading to equal chances of affecting both sexes.
  • • Option B. Autosomal recessive
  • • Option D. Mitochondrial : Incorrect. Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by maternal transmission, where affected males do not pass the trait, but all offspring of affected females inherit it.
  • • Option D. Mitochondrial

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ X-linked dominant inheritance is characterized by affected males passing the trait to all their daughters but none of their sons, while affected females transmit the condition to 50% of their offspring. Understanding this inheritance pattern aids in distinguishing X-linked conditions from other genetic disorders.

questions.text: A patient with occupational exposure to benzene presents with repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature. This occupational exposure will predispose him to which of the following cancers? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leukemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Occupational exposure to benzene predisposes individuals to leukemia, as benzene metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, leading to marrow aplasia and various types of leukemia. The clinical presentation of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature in a patient with benzene exposure is highly suggestive of leukemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key features to differentiate necrosis from apoptosis include the state of cell organelles (intact in apoptosis, disintegrated in necrosis), enzyme-mediated degradation (present in necrosis), and internal organelle disintegration with lipid changes (present in necrosis). Altered cell shape alone is not a useful parameter for differentiation.
